definition:
Let $\Gamma$ be a Lie group acting on a vector space $V$ and let the
system of ordinary differential equations
$$\dot{\mathbf{x}} + g(\mathbf{x},\lambda)=0$$ where
$g\colon\mathbb{R}^n \times \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}^n$ is smooth. Then
$g$ is called a *bifurcation problem with symmetry group* $\Gamma$ if
$g\in \vec{\mathcal{E}}_{x,\lambda}(\Gamma)$ *(where
$\vec{\mathcal{E}}(\Gamma)$ is the space of $\Gamma$-equivariant germs,
at the origin, of $C^\infty$ mappings of $V$ into $V$)* satisfying
$$g(0,0)=0$$ and $$(dg)_{0,0} = 0$$ where $(dg)_{0,0}$ denotes the
Jacobian Matrix evaluated at $(0,0)$. [@1]

[1]{} Golubitsky, Martin. Stewart, Ian. Schaeffer, G. David.:
Singularities and Groups in Bifurcation Theory *(Volume II)*.
Springer-Verlag, New York, 1988.
